choices.text: Distal fragment of ulna is displaced upwards and backwards
Distal fragment of Ulna is displaced upwards and forwards
Distal fragment of radius is displaced upwards and backwards
Distal fragment of radius is displaced upwards and forwards

questions.text: A 70 years old male came to OPD with pain & swelling on lower end of right forearm. He had a history of falling on outstretched hand. On x-ray examination it shows smith's fracture. Which of the following deformity will be there in this patient?
questions.solution:
Topic: Bone_radius

>

Colles' fracture:

  • The radius commonly gets fractured about 2 cm above its lower end.
  • This fracture is caused by a fall on the outstretched hand.
  • The distal fragment is displaced upwards and backwards.
  • The radial styloid process comes to lie proximal to the ulnar styloid process. (It normally lies distal to the ulnar styloid process.)

Smith's fracture:

  • If the distal fragment gets displaced anteriorly and upwards, it is called Smith’s fracture.
  • It is also known as reverse Colles' fracture.

(A) Colles' Fracture & (B) Smith's Fracture

Reference: Textbook of B. D. Chaurasia, Volume-1, 9th Edition, Page Number – 21, 24

choices.text: It is the only long bone that lies horizontally
It is the first bone to start ossification
It has one primary and one secondary centres of ossification

questions.text: 50 years old men falled from height. He had a fracture of clavicle at the junction of medial 2/3rd and lateral 1/3rd. Which of the following is false about fractured bone?
questions.solution:
Topic: Bone_clavicle

  • The clavicle is commonly fractured by falling on the outstretched hand (indirect violence).
  • The most common site of fracture is the junction between the two curvatures of the bone, which is the weakest point.
  • The lateral fragment is displaced downwards by the weight of the limb as trapezius muscle alone is unable to support the weight of upper limb.

Peculiarities of the Clavicle:

  • It is the only long bone that lies horizontally.
  • It is subcutaneous throughout.
  • It is the first bone to start ossifying.
  • It is the only long bone which ossifies in membrane.
  • It is the only long bone which has two primary centres of ossification.
  • There is no medullary cavity.
  • It is occasionally pierced by the middle supraclavicular nerve.
  • It receives weight of upper limb via lateral one-third through coracoclavicular ligament and transmits weight of upper limb to the axial skeleton via medial two-thirds part.

Reference: Textbook of B. D. Chaurasia, Volume-1, 9th Edition, Page Number - 6, 8

choices.text: The Midsternal line to midaxillary line
The lateral border of the sternum to the midaxillary line
The Midsternal line to the midclavicular line
The lateral border of the sternum to the midclavicular line

questions.text: 60 years old lady came to OPD with C/O discharge from nipple, asymmetry of mammary gland and mass in right breast. She was diagnosed with carcinoma of mammry gland. Which of the following is true about horizontal extent of mammary gland?
questions.solution:
Topic: Pectoral region _ mammary gland

  • The upper and outer quadrant of breast is a frequent site of carcinoma (cancer). The first lymph node draining the tumour-bearing area is called 'sentinal node.' Abscesses may also form in the breast and may require drainage. The following facts are worthy of note.
  • Cancer of the mammary glands is the most common cancer in females of all ages.
  • It is more frequently seen in postmenopausal females due to lack of oestrogen hormones.

The mammary gland:

  • The breast lies in the superficial fascia of the pectoral region.
  • It is divided into four quadrants, i.e. upper medial, upper lateral, lower medial and lower lateral.
  • A small extension of the upper lateral quadrant, called the axillary tail of Spence, passes through an opening in the deep fascia and lies in the axilla.
  • The opening is called foramen of Langer. Its base is circular.
  • The breast lies in the superficial fascia of the pectoral region.
  • Vertically, it extends from the second to the sixth ribs.
  • Horizontally, it extends from the lateral border of the sternum to the midaxillary line.

Reference: Textbook of B. D. Chaurasia, Volume-1, 9th Edition, Page Number - 40, 45

questions.text: 40 years old worker falled form 3rd floor. He hold rod during falling. He was diagnosed with Klumpke's paralysis. What will be the site of injury in this case?
questions.solution:
Topic: Axilla_brachial plexus

Klumpke's Paralysis:

  • Site of injury:
    • Lower trunk of the brachial plexus.
  • Cause of injury:
    • Undue abduction of the arm, as in clutching something with the hands after a fall from a height, or sometimes in birth injury.
  • Nerve roots involved:
    • Mainly T1 and partly C8.
  • Muscles paralysed:
    • Intrinsic muscles of the hand (T1) and ulnar flexors of the wrist and fingers (C8).
  • Deformity and position of the hand:
    • Claw hand due to the unopposed action of the long flexors and extensors of the fingers.
    • In a claw hand, there is hyperextension at the metacarpophalangeal joints and flexion at the interphalangeal joints.
  • Disability:
    • Complete claw hand
    • Cutaneous anaesthesia and analgesia in a narrow zone along the ulnar border of the forearm and hand.
    • Horner's syndrome: If T1 is injured proximal to white ramus communicans to first thoracic sympathetic ganglion, there is ptosis, miosis, anhydrosis, enophthalmos, and loss of ciliospinal reflex. This is because of injury to sympathetic fibres to the head and neck that leave the spinal cord through nerve T1.
  • Vasomotor changes:
    • The skin area with sensory loss is warmer due to arteriolar dilation.
    • It is also drier due to the absence of sweating as there is loss of sympathetic activity.
  • Trophic changes:
    • Long-standing case of paralysis leads to dry and scaly skin.
    • The nails crack easily with atrophy of the pulp of fingers.

Reference: Textbook of B. D. Chaurasia, Volume-1, 9th Edition, Page Number - 65

choices.text: One primary centre and seven secondary centres
Two primary centre and Five secondary centres
One primary centre and Five secondary centres
Two primary centre and seven secondary centres

questions.text: 45 years old patient diagnosed with injury of long thoracic nerve. The bone which becomes prominent during pushing movement in this patient, is ossifies from?
questions.solution:
Topic: Scapular region & scapula bone

Winging of scapula

  • Paralysis of the serratus anterior produces 'winging of scapula' in which the inferior angle and the medial border of the scapula are unduly prominent.
  • The patient is not able to do any pushing action, nor can he raise his arm above the head. Any attempt to do these movements makes the inferior angle of the scapula still more prominent.
  • Causes of winging of scapula: Injury to long thoracic nerve
    • Sudden pressure on the shoulder from above.
    • Carrying heavy loads on the shoulder.
  • Deformity:
    • Winging of the scapula, i.e. excessive prominence of the medial border of the scapula.
    • Normally, the pull of the muscle keeps the medial border against the thoracic wall.
  • Disability:
    • Loss of pushing and punching actions. During attempts at pushing, there occurs winging of the scapula.
    • Overhead abduction of shoulder girdle is partly affected due to intact trapezius muslce.

Ossification of scapula:

  • The scapula ossifies from one primary centre and seven secondary centres.
  • The primary centre appears near the glenoid cavity during the eighth week of development.
  • The first secondary centre appears in the middle of the coracoid process during the first year and fuses by the 15th year.
  • The subcoracoid centre appears in the root of the coracoid process during the 10th year and fuses by the 16th to 18th years.
  • The other centres, including two for the acromion process, one for the lower two-thirds of the margin of the glenoid cavity, one for the medial border and one for the inferior angle, appear at puberty and fuse by the 25th year.
  • The fact of practical importance is concerned with the acromion process. If the two centres appearing for acromion process fail to unite, it may be interpreted as a fracture on radiological examination.
  • In such cases, a radiograph of the opposite acromion process will mostly reveal similar failure of union.

Reference: Textbook of B. D. Chaurasia, Volume-1, 9th Edition, Page Number - 12, 49, 66

choices.text: Lateral pectoral nerve, Thoracoacromial artery, Cephalic vein, Lymphatics
Medial pectoral nerve, Thoracoacromial artery, Cephalic vein, Lymphatics
Lateral pectoral nerve, Thoracoacromial artery, Basilic vein, Lymphatics
Medial pectoral nerve, Thoracoacromial artery, Basilic vein, Lymphatics

questions.text: Which of the following structures are piercing the clavipectoral fascia?
questions.solution:
Topic: Pectoral region

Clavipectoral fascia

  • It is a fibrous sheet situated deep to the clavicular portion of the pectoralis major muscle.
  • It extends from the clavicle above to the axillary fascia below.
  • Its upper part splits to enclose the subclavius muscle.
  • The posterior lamina is fused to the investing layer of the deep cervical fascia and to the axillary sheath.
  • Inferiorly, the clavipectoral fascia splits to enclose the pectoralis minor muscle.
  • Medially, it is attached to external intercostal muscle of upper intercostal spaces and laterally to coracoid process.
  • Below this muscle, it continues as the suspensory ligament which is attached to the dome of the axillary fascia, and helps to maintain it.
  • The clavipectoral fascia is pierced by the following structures.
    • Lateral pectoral nerve
    • Cephalic vein
    • Thoracoacromial artery
    • Lymphatics

Reference: Textbook of B. D. Chaurasia, Volume-1, 9th Edition, Page Number - 48

questions.text: 30 years old patient came to OPD with C/O difficulty in abduction his right arm at shoulder joint. On examination it was diagnosed that there was loss of round contour of right shoulder. There was also sensation loss in upper lateral part of arm. What is the root value of nerve involved in this patient?
questions.solution:
• The axillary nerve may be damaged by
    • Dislocation of the shoulder
    • By the fracture of the surgical neck of the humerus
    • Intermuscular injection in deltoid muscle
  • The effects produced are:
    • Rounded contour of shoulder is lost; greater tubercle of humerus becomes prominent
    • Deltoid is paralysed, with loss of the power of abduction up to 90° at the shoulder.
    • There is sensory loss over the lower half of the deltoid in a badge-like area called regimental badge.
  • Axillary nerve is also known as circumflex nerve.
    • It is an important nerve because it supplies the deltoid muscle which is the main abductor of the arm.
    • Surgically, it is important, because it is commonly involved in dislocations of the shoulder and in fractures of the surgical neck of the humerus.
    • The axillary nerve is a smaller terminal branch of the posterior cord of the brachial plexus (C5, C6).
  • Branches of axillary nerve:
    • In the quadrangular space, the nerve divides into anterior and posterior branches.
    • The anterior branch is accompanied by the posterior circumflex humeral vessels.
      • It winds around the surgical neck of the humerus, deep to the deltoid muscle supplying the deltoid and the skin over its anteroinferior part.
    • The posterior branch supplies the teres minor and the posterior part of the deltoid.
      • The nerve to the teres minor bears a pseudoganglion, i.e. fibrous tissue and fat without any neurons.
      • The posterior branch then pierces the deep fascia at the lower part of the posterior border of the deltoid and continues as the upper lateral cutaneous nerve of the arm.

Topic: Back and scapular region

Reference: Textbook of B. D. Chaurasia, Volume-1, 9th Edition, Page Number - 80, 81

choices.text: It is rich in sebaceous gland
It is devoid of the hair follicle
There is no fat in the areola

questions.text: Which of the following is true about areola?
questions.solution:
Topic: pectoral region _ mammary gland

The areola:

  • The skin surrounding the base of the nipple is pigmented and forms a circular area called the areola.
  • This region is rich in modified sebaceous glands, particularly at its outer margin.
  • These become enlarged during pregnancy and lactation to form raised tubercles of Montgomery.
  • Oily secretions of these glands lubricate the nipple and areola, and prevent them from cracking during lactation.
  • Apart from sebaceous glands, the areola also contains some sweat glands, and accessory mammary glands.
  • The skin of the areola and nipple is devoid of hair, and there is no fat subjacent to it.
  • Below the areola, lactiferous sinus lies where stored milk is seen.

Reference: Textbook of B. D. Chaurasia, Volume-1, 9th Edition, Page Number - 41

questions.text: 30 years old patient having stiffness in sternoclavicular joint. On examination, physician observed that patient is having difficulty in movements of scapula occurs in inferolateral compartment of the sternoclavicular joint. All of the following movements are affected, EXCEPT:
questions.solution:
Topic: Joints of upper limb

Movement of scapula - Compartment in which movement occurs:

  • Elevation of the scapula - Inferolateral compartment
  • Depression of scapula - Inferolateral compartment
  • Lateral or forward rotation of the scapula - Inferolateral compartment
  • Medial or backward rotation of the scapula - Inferolateral compartment
  • Retraction of the scapula - Superomedial compartment
  • Protraction of the scapula - Superomedial compartment

Reference: Textbook of B. D. Chaurasia, Volume-1, 9th Edition, Page Number - 161 to 163

questions.text: Anterior intercostal artery of 7th intercostal space is branch of?
questions.solution:
Topic: Thoracic wall

Anterior intercostal artery:

  • There are nine intercostal spaces anteriorly as only ten ribs reach front of body.
  • There are two anterior intercostal arteries in each space.
  • In the upper six spaces, they arise from the internal thoracic artery.
  • In seventh to ninth spaces, the arteries are branches of musculophrenic artery.
  • The two anterior intercostal arteries end at the costochondral junction by anastomosing with the respective posterior intercostal arteries and with the collateral branches of the posterior intercostal arteries.

Reference: Textbook of B. D. Chaurasia, Volume-1, 9th Edition, Page Number - 253

questions.text: 60 years old male patient was diagnosed with mass occupying in posterior mediastinum. All of the following structures are can be affected, EXCEPT:
questions.solution:
Contents of posterior mediastinum:

  • Oesophagus
  • Arteries: Descending thoracic aorta and its branches.
  • Veins:
    • Azygos vein
    • Hemiazygos vein
    • Accessory hemiazygos vein
  • Nerves:
    • Vagus nerve
    • Splanchnic nerves: Greater, lesser and least, arising from the lower eight thoracic ganglia of the sympathetic chain.
  • Lymph nodes and lymphatics: Posterior mediastinal lymph nodes lying along side the aorta.
  • The thoracic duct

Topic: Mediastinum

Reference: Textbook of B. D. Chaurasia, Volume-1, 9th Edition, Page Number – 286, 287

questions.text: 45 years old male patient is having C/O cough and breathless ness. On examination it was seen that, there is presence of fluid and air in the pleural cavity. What is the diagnosis in this patient?
questions.solution:
Topic: Pleura and lungs

Diseases of the Pleura

  • Pleurisy: This is inflammation of the pleura. It may be dry, but often it is accompanied by collection of fluid in the pleural cavity. The condition is called the pleural effusion.
  • Dry pleurisy is more painful because during inspiration both layers come in contact and there is friction.
  • Pneumothorax: Presence of air in the pleural cavity.
  • Haemothorax: Presence of blood in the pleural cavity.
  • Hydropneumothorax: Presence of both fluid and air in the pleural cavity.
  • Empyema: Presence of pus in pleural cavity.

Reference: Textbook of B. D. Chaurasia, Volume-1, 9th Edition, Page Number - 267. 268

choices.text: The 1st costal cartilage and 1st rib lie at this level
The decending aorta starts at this level
The Pulmonary plexus present at this level
Lies at the level of the disc between the 3rd and 4th thoracic vertebrae

questions.text: Which of the following statement is true about sternal angle?
questions.solution:
Sternal angle/angle of Louis:

  • It is felt as a transverse ridge about 5 cm below the suprasternal notch.
  • It marks the manubriosternal joint, and lies at the level of the second costal cartilage anteriorly, and the disc between the fourth and fifth thoracic vertebrae posteriorly.
  • This is an important landmark for the following reasons.
    • The ribs are counted from this level downwards. There is no other reliable point (anteriorly) from which the ribs may be counted. The second costal cartilage and second rib lie at the level of the sternal angle or angle of Louis.
    • It marks the plane which separates the superior mediastinum from the inferior mediastinum.
    • The ascending aorta ends at this level.
    • The arch of the aorta begins and also ends at this level.
    • The descending aorta begins at this level.
    • The trachea divides into two principal bronchi.
    • The azygos vein arches over the root of the right lung and opens into the superior vena cava.
    • The pulmonary trunk divides into two pulmonary arteries just below this level.
    • The thoracic duct crosses from the right to the left side at the level of the fifth thoracic vertebra and reaches the left side at the level of the sternal angle.
    • It marks the upper limit of the base of the heart.
    • The cardiac plexuses are situated at the same level.

Topic: Thoracic cage

Reference: Textbook of B. D. Chaurasia, Volume-1, 9th Edition, Page Number – 215

choices.text: Pressure on the recurrent laryngeal nerve

questions.text: 60 years old male patient diagnosed with mediastinal syndrome, which of the following is the reason behind the dysphonia?
questions.solution:
Mediastinal syndrome:

  • Compression of mediastinal structures by any tumour gives rise to a group of symptoms known as mediastinal syndrome.
  • The common symptoms are as follows:
  • Obstruction of superior vena cava gives rise to engorgement of veins in the upper half of the body.
  • Pressure over the trachea causes dyspnoea, and cough.
  • Pressure on oesophagus causes dysphagia.
  • Pressure or the left recurrent laryngeal nerve gives rise to hoarseness of voice (dysphonia).
  • Pressure on the phrenic nerve causes paralysis of the diaphragm on that side.
  • Pressure on the intercostal nerves gives rise to pain in the area supplied by them. It is called intercostal neuralgia.
  • Pressure on the vertebral column may cause erosion of the vertebral bodies.
  • The common causes of mediastinal syndrome are bronchogenic carcinoma, Hodgkin’s disease causing enlargement of the mediastinal lymph nodes, aneurysm or dilatation of the aorta, etc.

Topic: Mediastinum

Reference: Textbook of B. D. Chaurasia, Volume-1, 9th Edition, Page Number – 287, 288

questions.text: Left principal bronchus makes an aggle of _______ with trachea
questions.solution:
Topic : Lungs

Principal bronchus:

  • The trachea divides at the level of the lower border of the fourth thoracic vertebra into two primary principal bronchi, one for each lung.
  • The right principal bronchus: It is 2.5 cm long.
    • It is shorter, wider and more in line with the trachea than the left principal bronchus.
    • Inhaled particles or foreign bodies, therefore, tend to pass more frequently to the right lung, with the result that infections are more common on the right side than on the left.
    • Right bronchus makes an angle of 25° with tracheal bifurcation with the trachea.
  • The left principal bronchus: It is 5 cm long.
    • It is longer, narrower and more oblique than the right bronchus.
    • Left bronchus makes an angle of 45° with tracheal bifurcation with the trachea.

Reference: Textbook of B. D. Chaurasia, Volume-1, 9th Edition, Page Number - 276

questions.text: Which of the following ribs are vertebrochondral ribs?
questions.solution:
Topic :Thoracic wall

Ribs:

  • Each rib articulates posteriorly with the vertebral column.
  • Anteriorly, only the upper seven ribs articulate with the sternum through their cartilages and these are called true or vertebrosternal ribs.
  • The costal cartilages of the next three ribs, i.e. the eighth, ninth and tenth end by joining the next higher costal cartilage. These ribs are, therefore, known as vertebrochondral ribs.
    • The costal cartilages of the seventh, eighth, ninth and tenth ribs form the sloping costal margin.
  • The anterior ends of the eleventh and twelfth ribs are free: These are called floating or vertebral ribs.
  • The vertebrochondral and vertebral ribs, i.e. the last five ribs, are also called false ribs because they do not articulate with the sternum.

Reference: Textbook of B. D. Chaurasia, Volume-1, 9th Edition, Page Number - 225

choices.text: It is situated in anterior mediastinum
It ends at the level of lower border of the body of the fourth thoracic vertebra
The trachea lies anterior and left to the arch of aorta
Right common carotid artery is a one of the branch of it

questions.text: All of the following statements are false about arch of aorta, EXCEPT:
questions.solution:
Arch of the aorta:

  • It is the continuation of the ascending aorta.
  • It is situated in the superior mediastinum behind the lower half of the manubrium sterni.
  • Course
    • It begins behind the upper border of the second right sternochondral joint
    • It runs upwards, backwards and to the left across the left side of the bifurcation of trachea.
    • Then it passes downwards behind the left bronchus and on the left side of the body of the fourth thoracic vertebra.
    • It thus arches over the root of the left lung.
  • It ends at the lower border of the body of the fourth thoracic vertebra by becoming continuous with the descending aorta.
  • Thus the beginning and the end of arch of aorta are at the same level, although it begins anteriorly and ends posteriorly.
  • Relations:
    • Anteriorly and to the Left
      • Four nerves from before backwards:
        • Left phrenic
        • Lower cervical cardiac branch of the left vagus
        • Superior cervical cardiac branch of left sympathetic chain.
        • Left vagus
      • Left superior intercostal vein, deep to the phrenic nerve and superficial to the vagus nerve
      • Left pleura and lung
      • Remains of thymus
    • Posteriorly and to the Right
      • Trachea, with the deep cardiac plexus and the tracheobronchial lymph nodes
      • Oesophagus
      • Thoracic duct
      • Vertebral column
    • Superior
      • Three branches of the arch of the aorta:
      • All three arteries are crossed close to their origin by the left brachiocephalic vein.
    • Inferior
      • Bifurcation of the pulmonary trunk
      • Left bronchus
      • Ligamentum arteriosum with superficial cardiac plexus on it.
      • Left recurrent laryngeal nerve.
    • Branches:
      • Brachiocephalic artery which divides into the right common carotid and right subclavian arteries
      • Left common carotid artery
      • Left subclavian artery

Topic: Aorta

Reference: Textbook of B. D. Chaurasia, Volume-1, 9th Edition, Page Number – 319 to 321

questions.text: Esophagus is supplied by branches of all of the following artery EXCEPT
questions.solution:
Topic: Oesophagus

The oesophagus:

  • It is a narrow muscular tube, forming the food passage between the pharynx and stomach.
  • It extends from the lower part of the neck to the upper part of the abdomen.
  • The oesophagus is about 25 cm long.
  • Blood Supply:
    • The cervical part including the segment up to the arch of aorta is supplied by the inferior thyroid arteries.
    • The thoracic part is supplied by the oesophageal branches of the aorta.
    • The abdominal part is supplied by the oesophageal branches of the left gastric artery.
  • Venous Drainage:
    • Blood from the upper part of the oesophagus drains into the brachiocephalic veins.
    • Blood from the middle part it goes to the azygos veins.
    • Blood from the lower end it goes to the left gastric vein and vena azygos via hemiazygos vein.
    • The lower end of the oesophagus is one of the sites of portosystemic anastomoses.

Reference: Textbook of B. D. Chaurasia, Volume-1, 9th Edition, Page Number - 331, 332

questions.text: Coronary sinus drain into which of the following part of heart?
questions.solution:
Topic: Heart

Coronary sinus:

  • The coronary sinus is the largest vein of the heart.
  • It is situated in the left posterior coronary sulcus.
  • It is about 3 cm long.
  • It ends by opening into the posterior wall of the right atrium.
  • Tributaries of coronary sinus:
    • The great cardiac vein accompanies first the anterior interventricular artery and then the circumflex artery to enter the left end of the coronary sinus
    • The middle cardiac vein accompanies the posterior interventricular artery, and joins the middle part of the coronary sinus.
    • The small cardiac vein accompanies the right coronary artery in the right posterior coronary sulcus and joins the right end of the coronary sinus. The right marginal vein may drain into the small cardiac vein.
    • The posterior vein of the left ventricle runs on the diaphragmatic surface of the left ventricle and ends in the coronary sinus.
    • The oblique vein of the left atrium of Marshall is a small vein running on the posterior surface of the left atrium. It terminates in the left end of the coronary sinus.
    • The right marginal vein accompanies the marginal branch of the right coronary artery. It may either drain into the small cardiac vein, or may open directly into the right atrium.

Reference: Textbook of B. D. Chaurasia, Volume-1, 9th Edition, Page Number - 308

questions.text: 32 years old patient met with an accident. He had nerve injury. After MRI Scan it was diagnosed that there is an interruption of axon with preservation of myelin sheath. What it is known as?
questions.solution:
Topic: General Anatomy of nervous system

Degeneration of Nerve after injury:

  • The injuries to peripheral nerves are quite common.
  • They may occur due to compression, traction, trauma, interamuscular injection, cut wounds, etc.
  • There are three types of nerve injuries as follows:
    • Neurotmesis: Interruption of axon and its myelin sheath.
    • Axonotmesis: Interruption of axon with preservation of myelin sheath.
    • Neuropraxia: Both axon and its myelin sheath are preserved.
  • Recovery can occur in case of neuropraxia and axonotmesis.
  • There is some degree of function loss is inevitable.

Reference: General Anatomy by Vishram Singh, 4th Edition, Page Number - 172

questions.text: 25 years old women met with a road traffic accident. she visited OPD with C/O pain and swelling over knee joint. She was diagnosed with fracture of patella bone. Which of the following is incorrect about fractured bone?
questions.solution:
Topic: General Anatomy of bone

  • Patella is a largest sesamoid bone
  • Sesamoid bones: These are bony nodules found embedded in the tendons or joint capsules.
  • They have no periosteum and ossify after birth.
  • They are related to an articular or nonarticular bony surface, and the surfaces of contact are covered with hyaline cartilage and lubricated by a bursa or synovial membrane.
  • There is no Haversion system.
  • Examples: Patella
    • Pisiform
    • Fabella
  • Functions of the sesamoid bones are:
    • To resist pressure;
    • To minimise friction;
    • To alter the direction of pull of the muscle;
    • To maintain the local circulation.

Reference: General Anatomy by Vishram Singh, 4th Edition, Page Number - 67

questions.text: Which of the following structure covers the fasciculi of nerve fibres?
questions.solution:
Topic: General Anatomy of nervous system

Peripheral nerves:

  • The nerves are solid white cords composed of bundles (fasciculi) of nerve fibres.
  • Each nerve fibre is an axon with its coverings.
  • The nerve fibres are supported and bound together by connective tissue sheaths at different levels of organization of the nerve.
  • The whole nerve trunk is ensheathed by epineurium.
  • Each fasciculus of nerve ensheathed by perineurium.
  • Each nerve fibre ensheathed by a delicate endoneurium.
  • The toughness of a nerve is due to its fibrous sheaths; otherwise the nerve tissue itself is very delicate and friable.
  • However, all the fibres whether myelinated or non-myelinated have a neurolemmal sheath, which is uniformly absent in the tracts.
  • In peripheral nerves, both the myelin and neurolemmal sheaths are derived from Schwann cells.

Reference: General Anatomy by Vishram Singh, 4th Edition, Page Number - 169, 171

questions.text: According to functional classification, veins are classified under which of the following vessles?
questions.solution:
Topic: General Anatomy of Cardiovascular system

Blood vessels:

  • Functionally, the blood vessels can be classified into the following five groups.
  • Conducting vessels:
    • Including large arteries (elastic arteries).
  • Distributing vessels
    • Including medium sized arteries (muscular arteries).
  • Resistance vessels:
    • Including arterioles and precapillary sphincters.
  • Exchange vessels:
    • Including capillaries, sinusoids, and postcapillary venules.
  • Reservoir (capacitance) vessels:
    • Including larger venules and veins.
  • Shunts:
    • Including various types of anastomoses.

Reference: General Anatomy by Vishram Singh, 4th Edition, Page Number - 138

questions.text: Who is known as Father of Modern Anatomy?
questions.solution:
• Father of Anatomy: Herophilus
  • Father of Modern Anatomy: Vesalius
  • Father of Surgery: Sushruta
  • Father of Medicine: Hippocrates
  • Father of Histology: Marcelo Malpighi
  • Father of Genetics: Gregor Johann Mendel
  • Term Anatomy was coined by: Aristotle
  • First scientist to dissect the human body: Herophilus
  • Prince of Physicians: Claudius Galen

Topic: Anatomical terminology and history

Reference: General Anatomy by Vishram Singh, 4th Edition, Page Number - 9, 10

questions.text: All of the following sentences are true about neurons, EXCEPT:
questions.solution:
Topic: General Anatomy of nervous system

  • The nervous tissue is composed of two distinct types of cells:
    • The excitable cells are the nerve cells or neurons; and
    • The non-excitable cells constitute neuroglia and ependyma in the CNS, and Schwann cells in the PNS.
  • Neuron:
    • They are the structural and functional units of the nervous system.
    • Total numbar: about 100 billion.
    • Two main properties: Excitability and Conductivity.
    • They are specialized for reception, integration, transformation and transmission of impluses.
    • They are highly differentiated cells.
    • They have lost their power of division.
    • There are no centrioles and centrosomes in the nerve cell body.
    • They are highly specialized cells.
    • Hach nerve cell or neuron has:
      • A cell body or perikaryon, having a central nucleus and Nissl granules in its cytoplasm.
      • Cell processes called neurites, which are of two types. Many short afferent processes, which are freely branching and varicose, are called dendrites.
      • Single long efferent process called axon, which may give off occasional branches (collaterals) and is of uniform diameter.
      • The terminal branches of the axon are called axon terminals or telodendria.

Reference: General Anatomy by Vishram Singh, 4th Edition, Page Number - 166
